programme.desc: OpenAI releases its latest video generation model, which it claims is more physically accurate, realistic and controllable than prior systems. programme.title: The Interview
programme.desc: In his own words, Sir Anthony Hopkins describes how a deeply troubled boy from Port Talbot, Wales, achieved two-time Oscar glory in Hollywood. Deemed a failure by his parents, peers and teachers, Sir Anthony Hopkins has triumphed in memorable roles like Hannibal Lecter, King Lear and the Pope. His extraordinary journey was paved with pain, rejection and addiction but was ultimately saved by love. As his memoir is published, the actor meets Katie Razzall in Los Angeles to tell his remarkable story.

programme.title: Access All Areas
programme.desc: Sparkles, sequins and shed loads of self-tan. We're behind the scenes at the real Strictly Come Dancing, as the British National Dance Championships celebrates its 50th anniversary. We follow three couples from practice to performance, and hopefully to podium. Professionals Petar Daskalov and Zia James are chasing the Latin trophy for a second year running. Eleven-year-old partners Leo and Chloe, who have been dancing together for just a year, are hoping to shine in both Latin and Ballroom. And after six attempts at the Amateur Ballroom Championships, Andrei Toader and Mia Linnik-Holden are back on the dance floor, hoping it's seventh time lucky.

programme.title: Global Women
programme.desc: Greenlandic parents across Denmark are fighting to be reunited with their children, who were taken into care after authorities used 'parenting competency tests' as part of assessments to judge their ability to raise them. After banning the tests for use on Greenlandic people, the Danish government has now pledged to review around 300 child removals, but not everyone's cases are being looked at.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest news from the BBC.

programme.title: The Media Show
programme.desc: Jeremy Vine joins The Media Show to discuss his recent court victories over Joey Barton, the former footballer who earlier this month received a suspended prison sentence for offensive social media posts. The case has raised questions about where criticism ends and criminal conduct begins. The mass shooting at Bondi Beach during a Hanukkah event created major challenges for journalists trying to confirm fast-moving details. Newsrooms had to decide how to describe the attack, when to name suspects, and how to treat unverified online posts. Jacqueline Maley, senior writer at the Sydney Morning Herald, explains the decisions behind early reporting and the influence of social media. In Florida, Donald Trump has filed a defamation case against the BBC over an edited sequence in the Panorama documentary, which triggered the resignation of the corporation's Director General and its CEO of News. Stuart M Benjamin, professor of law at Duke University, sets out the legal issues.

programme.title: The Interview
programme.desc: Patti Smith: singer, poet, artist, activist and writer who has influenced artists including Taylor Swift and Dua Lipa. Smith's extraordinary career has spanned more than 50 years during which the poet of punk has refused to conform to stereotypes of what a woman artist should be. Now she reveals how a DNA test led her to re-evaluate her own story. As her memoir is published, Smith tells Katie Razzall the book is written in gratitude to all the people she's lost.

And Tom Gerken checks out the new Football Manager game.

programme.desc: The latest news from the BBC.

programme.title: Discovering the World's Table
programme.desc: Food writer Nick Kwek journeys to his ancestral homeland of Sabah in Malaysian Borneo, exploring its rich culinary heritage shaped by tribal traditions and global influences. He begins by island-hopping with the Bajau Laut, a seafaring community whose free-diving and spear-hunting skills bring the freshest seafood to their native dishes. In Kota Kinabalu, Nick meets chef Raphael Lee, who reinvents traditional hinava with a modern twist for international visitors. Venturing into Sabah's lush valleys, Nick learns the art of rice wine-making with the Dusun Gana people and experiences their vibrant magunatip bamboo dancing. Returning to the capital, Nick savours chef Linn Yong's inventive cocktails and dishes, which showcase the multicultural flavours of the region. Through food, culture and community, Nick uncovers the soul of Sabah in every bite.

programme.title: BBC News
programme.desc: The latest news from the BBC.

programme.title: Talking Movies
programme.desc: Tom Brook and the Talking Movies team look back on some of the biggest film moments of the year. From the California wildfires to debates around artificial intelligence and the rise of independent cinema at this year's Oscars, it has been an eventful 12 months. Tom reflects on his personal highlights, including a behind-the-scenes look at a day in the life of a film journalist at the Cannes Film Festival and an exploration of a new wave of British cinema with first-time filmmakers Imran Perretta, Harry Lighton and Ronan Day-Lewis, directors of Ish, Pillion and Anemone. The team revisit some of their favourite films of 2025, and Emma Jones examines the growing global success of African cinema. Finally, continuing his annual tradition, Tom reveals his top ten films from the many he's watched in 2025.

programme.title: On the Front Line
programme.desc: Missing for over 100 years - the human remains of two Scottish soldiers, killed in 1915 during the Battle of Loos in northern France, are uncovered by construction workers. The bodies lie missing for over a century until the war detectives, using archaeology and specialist research, track down the living relatives of 23-year-old Lance Corporal Gordon McPherson and 20-year-old Lieutenant James Allan. Finally, the names of these two young soldiers will be engraved on headstones as they are laid to rest, alongside thousands of others, with full military honours.
